It was really not as good as the first two but that's not saying much either it was just ok that's all
I was less impressed with this one.

Following suit of its predecessors, V/H/S: VIRAL takes its great anthology premise and sloppily squashes it! This time we get one slightly entertaining segment that carelessly breaks the found-footage rules (Dante the Great), a wonderfully set up segment that ends in some ridiculous puppetry (Parallel Monsters), an able-bodied segment that quickly turns into a foul-mouthed teenagers pipe-dream (Bonestorm), and a choppy, nonsensical wrap-around to bring it all together. Not quite as disappointing as V/H/S or insulting as V/H/S 2 - somewhere in the murky middle, where franchises usually go to die.

This is a pretty big letdown from the first two movies, as I don't think it really knew what it was supposed to be and was poorly executed (pardon the pun). The magician story was neat, but not of the style I'd expect from this series, the skater story at the end was ok, but the alternate universe one in the middle was the only saving grace as it was messed up.

It's hard to believe that V/H/S Viral is even related to the unique, intriguing series of the shame name that showed a lot of potential for growth. Viral is instead an utterly stupid, colossus of a failure on every level.
A big stumble for a series I have loved thus far. One good segment, one bad segment and one unfinished segment; wrapped in an ambitious but misguided framework story.

This epic conclusion to the anthology series [V/H/S (2012) & V/H/S 2 (2013)] is much more crazier & epic! I definitely enjoyed Viral MORE than I did with the previous two films. As its predecessors, V/H/S Viral is formed by three found-footage stories, tied together by yet a fourth frame story, also filmed in a found-footage fashion. (Apparently there was supposed to be one more segment, directed by Todd Lincoln, but it was never filmed or it didn't make the final cut) All the four stories have an innovative touch to them; they may start of a bit strange, but trust me you would be paralyzed with shock & awe the moment you realize where the story has lead to. Compared to the last two outings this one is actually low on horror but nonetheless creeps you out. The directors & producers behind V/H/S: Viral have made sure the V/H/S series ended its run on a high note, instead of falling under its own success like most horror franchises do! Must watch for found footage & horror fans!!

VHS: Viral is a disappointing and bland horror anthology film. While the film's first short is intriguing and shows potential for the film the rest of the film's shorts are poorly executed and range from bad to atrocious. Many elements of the film feel rushed and poorly directed with some abysmal camera work and narrative structure. The films last short is an embarrassment to the series and is executed so poorly and features such unlikable characters it's near impossible to sit through. A social message is implemented into the film, but hinders the film and feels forced and pretentious especially during the film's last act. With the exception of the film's first skit, every character is unlikable and poorly written to the point where any suspense or scares are non existent.

The first time I saw it, I hated it. But with a second viewing, it's fast, entertaining fun. The three segments are great, even if the final one could've been longer. The main storyline is trash tough.
V/H/S: Viral is weak, confusing and lacks the creativity that made the first two installments such a success.

an absolutely inane, mind numbingly idiotic mess of a film. it's frantic, messy, I didn't know what was going on half of the time because of the choppy editing and terrible filmmaking. I really liked the first two V/H/S films but this one is a disgrace to those two. I really hated this one and couldn't wait to turn it off. the only reason this gets one star is because of the Parallel Dimension short. that was its only redeeming quality. save your time and do something better for an hour and 20 minutes.

I was really forward to this movie, but it ended up not what I wanted it to be.

V/H/S: viral is about a  big viral video in order to launch their "careers" instead find themselves becoming part of the latest Internet sensations - with fatal consequences. 

Before I start this review I have seen the other V/H/S movies and to me I thought those films was actually really shocking but still fun to watch, and when I heard this movie was coming out I was looking forward to it, and the trailers got me excited for the film, and after seeing the film... am a bit disappointing. This is a found footage movie and you know the camera is going to be all over the place, but in this movie the camera moved around so much that I couldn't see a damn thing and that annoyed me so much, because in the other V/H/S movies the camera did move around a lot, but not to the point where it annoyed me. And the movie is not scary at all or even shocking. But the only good thing in this movie that stopped me from giving this movie 1/5, is the skateboard scene with the hooded skeletons attacking the skateboarder's, and why I like that scene is because it comes out of nowhere and that's what made the other movies so fun. Overall I was really disappointing with this film. It's the worst, but it's not good.
The most disappointing end to a trilogy of all time.

What a disappointment. The first VHS was a flawed yet very entertaining horror flick, the sequel was a great horror film with some very unique segments, viral on the other hand has only one legitimately good segment, which was the first. The problem with viral is that in each of the segments there's something that messes it up, the first one was very entertaining and unique, and the character of Dante the great was very entertaining, but the segment isn't very thrilling. The second one was interesting but they never explained anything, that worked in the previous films but not here. The final segment would've been ok if the characters weren't unlikable and if the short wasn't a rip off of Safe Haven from the first. So in the end its not god awful like every one says, but its pretty bad.

This movie isn't as good as it's predecessors but still has some brilliant moments in it. So much so, I hope for a 4th. There were a few disappointing moments throughout but there are more moments that shine bright. It's brutal, violent but has lost the sex appeal it once had.

Not as bad as it's made out to be. I actually thoroughly enjoyed this one. Different from the other 2 but still lots of fun. Weakest of the series but that's not saying a lot as the VHS series is one of my favorite horror series ever.
Is this was any crappier it would be a toilet on the outside of a gas station.
Loved the last two... but this one was average for me.

Bad. Even by the series' own slightly lower standards. Weighted down by a budget that they felt they had to use, this entry in the franchise reached way too far. Two of the three shorts, plus the through story, were far more action oriented than they should have been. That said, there is one that stands out as being particularly great. But being sandwiched between garbage bogs down the experience. This film was, frankly, embarrassing for me as an avid fan of the franchise. Breaking its own rules in favor of a more "cinematic" look, VHS: Viral thinks it's much better than it is, thinks it has societal commentary, and takes itself far too seriously in the wrong ways, and too lightly in other ways. All in all, I think the filmmaker's collective egos may have ended their own modest franchise. If you're a fan of the series, I recommend watching the film anyway. It's like watching the fall of Valhalla. Both grand and terrible in its  destruction.
A messed up movie. Parallel Monsters was my favorite.  Had some nast laughs its more a black comedy horror thriller film.Not really what i thought it would be.

compared to the previous two films, V/H/S : Viral feels like the neglected child in a family. It's lacking the fear that the first two presented, but keeps on point with the gore and absurdity. The first two made me jump and cover my face, but this movie was much more tame, and didn't have the same scare factor.

Such a disappointment. 

The film felt very cheap, and was very empty. It felt like something was missing the entire time, and in its 1 hour and 20 minute running time it actually got kind of boring. 

The shorts had originality, that's true, but they all felt as if they were missing something. The first short was very original, but it wasn't scary, very campy, and WAY to short. 

The second one felt as if it was supposed trying to be Safe Haven from the second one, but derailed 2/3rds of the way trough. 

The third one was neat, the characters were fun. However towards the end it dragged on and felt irrational and felt extraordinarily foolish. 

The underlining story was interesting, and had some new moments, but was unfurnished, and had some problems. 

Overall the film was a grave disappointment. The absence of Simon Barret and Adam Wingard was gravely missed.
Just awful!!  I thought the first two VHS were somewhat entertaining, but this one is just plain bad
An alright follow up, though the "oomph" and novelty is starting to wear off.

After much white noise and other loud sounds along with annoying picture fluctuations, the individual horror segments begin. None of them are impressive. I recognize that it's part of the great horror tradition to beat a marketable name into the ground, but that doesn't make up for the disappointment. Out the three, this is the worst, it's problem lies is it's own demise, if you've seen the first two then you'll know what to expect, except this one isn't shocking nor fun to watch. Good twist at the end and the young cast are good but it lacks spice from a weak script. However, it does end an interesting trilogy but I'd stick with the bloody gory second film and the first film that shocked the shaky cam-doc genre. One need go no further than the film's first segment to grasp how little interest the latest entry in the anthology series has in generating chills from the lo-fi.
Still not a good movie, V/H/S/Viral is probably the best of the trilogy and it makes me glad the franchise is over.

Least favorite of the trilogy. The anthology strategy was clever and it wrapped around with satisfying "what you should expect"  from a third installment. The route being "viral" takes away from what was appealing in the first two films. Mild scares and corny 80's creepshowesque  plot gave me a love/hate feeling throughout. Overall it was a fast paced, "in your face" creation with camera angles that were ingeniously executed to create originality at every opportunity possible, but aside from it's predecessors uses the "shock" factor rather than terror and gritty disturbances that made the others terrifying as it's main target of reaction. So constant, that Its clear to expect almost immediately every scene was going to include some sort of WTF moment. Which is good for some and bad for others depending on your attention span. There's definite credability for the directors taking advantage of every single frame as an opportunity for visual enthrallment, but for me ,it was overkill to the point where all else at some point lacked surprise and just turned into a "that was cool" mindset. Every moment became a predictable crafty output minute by minute until the final act, which made the entire film feel like they rushed areas of creativity that were overworkked at something that could've been a lot more visually pleasing and less bothersome. The foundation of the movie was glued with force feeding the audience as much eye engaging trickery as possible in 90 minutes. There is definitely going to be a biased audience on whether or not it worked in their favor. As for me, the creativity was overfed and backfired.

ruins what could have been the biggest cult horror series with the right talent but this film shows it has reached the end.
